top_categories.workout_context: Big Horn Gravel's Rugged singletrack, Alpine mountain roads forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 85 miles.
118ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Big Horn Gravel's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before June.
At Big Horn Gravel, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
10,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
10,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Big Horn Gravel. Train it until it feels boring.
At mile 60 of 85, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Big Horn Gravel, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 85 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
Low-cadence force work for 10,000ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.
Smooth pedaling at 85 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Big Horn Gravel’s 85 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Big Horn Gravel with 10,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Dehydration and altitude stress; Long exposure at elevation compounds fatigue.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Big Horn Gravel demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride rugged jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: rugged singletrack, alpine mountain roads, backcountry blm/jeep roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 85 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, TT Threshold, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 85 miles of rugged jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt in Gypsum, Colorado.
